Column2: Tokyo After 5: Small Group Food, Drink & Culture Tour
Column7: This is an excellent pick for travelers interested in trying a variety of Japanese food specialties in one evening. Eliminate potential language barriers in restaurants by going on a hassle-free tour with a guide to translate and explain the dishes to you. Highlights include trying grilled meat skewers (yakitori), savory pancakes (monjayaki), sweets (wagashi), and sake.
Column14:
Highlights
A great way to learn about local Japanese cuisine from a guide
Lots of variety—three food tastings and two local drinks are included
Get top tips on great Tokyo bars and restaurants
No overcrowding—go on a small group tour limited to 8 people
See itinerary

Column2: Inside Tokyo’s Kitchen: Tsukiji Market & Culinary Culture Tour
Column7: Enjoy a fantastic foodie experience in Tokyo by exploring the outer Tsukiji Fish Market with a guide so you don’t get lost. Learn about the fish as you walk around, with no language obstacles as your guide will help translate. You’ll also learn about local culture by visiting a couple of nearby shrines. This culinary adventure is ideal for fish lovers, but you don’t have to be.

Column41:
We had a surprise private tour with Yoshi and had a wonderful time. We tried many yummy foods, both fish and otherwise.
Yoshi was very knowledgeable about Tokyo’s history and it was cool to learn about food, religion, and culture all on one tour. It was a very relaxed atmosphere and took place before the market got too crowded.
My favorite thing about this tour was that we were guided to places I would have never found on my own. I definitely would have not tried some of my favorite things I’ve had on this trip if not for this tour.

Column2: Private Melbourne: Fitzroy, Collingwood, Culture, Coffee, History
Column7: Dive deeper into different aspects of the inner-city neighborhoods of Fitzroy and Collingwood in Melbourne on this private tour. Learn how the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land and migrant communities have shaped (Naarm) Melbourne’s history, culture, and even coffee. Find out about the projects taking place at the STREAT social enterprise and walk through cultural hubs like the Collingwood Yards and Smith Street.

Column41:
We hadn't been to these neighborhoods before and had an awesome afternoon learning more about Fitzroy and Collingwood . Our Guide Tristan was informative and it was obvious he loved the area, it's culture, art and music scene (and some pretty nifty short cuts ; ) It was so cool to be shown around by a local and getting inside tips on things that were going on like the cool markets with local artists work and great local souvenirs while getting to know about the area's past, present and future.
A great way to get planning your next visit to the area. Get into it!

Column49: Collingwood is an inner-city Melbourne suburb, which was immortalized as "Carringbush" in Frank Hardy's epic novel "Power Without Glory." Collingwood is no longer a down at heel extension of Melbourne, it's super trendy with coffee shops, eateries, craft breweries and art galleries. Collingwood is a good place to walk around, you can get the vibe that this suburb famous.

Column20:
What an experience!

My family and I had a great time with Komang. We loved going to the night food market and trying some traditional Balinese dishes. They were all really yummy and unique.

Komang spoke incredible English and was very friendly. He even taught us some phrases in the local Balinese language. He was very kind and attentive, ensuring we had everything we needed at all times.

This was a brilliant tour and is definitely something you should do if you’re looking for an authentic and local experience.

Column56: Great food tastes and excellent guide

Wira was really good in his explanations and answering our questions about local foods.

Column2: Unlock Teotihuacan Pyramids: Private Tour & Delicious Local Lunch
Column7: Gain a new perspective on Mexican history on this half-day tour of the ancient pyramids of Teotihuacan. No need to plan logistics on your own: All admission tickets are included and a guide navigates the journey for you. After experiencing the view from the top of a pyramid, enjoy a home-cooked meal at the home of a local family, where your bilingual guide facilitates the conversation.

Column17: A unique trip to Teotihuacan from Mexico City
Column20:
Went on May 9th to see Teotihuacan, and I happened to be the only guest attending the tour! The trip was super interesting and unconventional, we started by using public transport to go from the city center to a bus hub and then took an overland bus to go straight to the ruins - including some introduction to the surrounding area and vendors / musicians live on the bus :D.
Arriving at Teotihuacan it definitely pays to have a knowledgeable guide and I learned a whole lot about the history and culture of the place, including opportunities to look at some in-depth archeology in the attached museum. Notably, we also visited a local shop with produce and the obsidian crafts that played a role in the history of this area. The trip ends with homemade Mexican food at a local home, which was very yummy!
My tour guide was super friendly and communicative both in English and Spanish and clearly well informed about Teotihuacan as well as every place along the way!
We went back on the bus and I returned to my place with no issues. Would definitely recommend the tour for anybody looking to see Teotihuacan based in Mexico City, this is the coolest way to do it!

Column86: The guide, Jacinto, was very friendly and knowledgeable and responded to us as individuals (there were only two of us on this tour). The excursion, however, finished two hours early: the 'dining experience' was in reality a bowl of Pozele served to us in a kitchen with just ourselves and Jacinto. Not very satisfactory at all and certainly not living up to the description (or other food based 'Urban Adventures' I have done in other parts of the world). Teotihuacun, however, was truly impressive and having Jacinto with us made for an 'easier' trip than navigating our own way on public transport. Visit could perhaps have included some time at the Museo at the pyramid site (but, I am sure, had this been mentioned, Jacinto would have incorporated it into the programme). The "local dinner" was the real con!

Column103:
This was an excellent tour that was much more than a visit to the site of Teotihuacan. Since I was the only person booked for this day day, it was essentially a private tour. My guide, Adriana, was enthusiastic and knowledgeable and I felt very confident traveling with her. In addition to seeing the ancient site, I enjoyed learning about obsidian carving from a local artist. I also learned about the many uses of the agave plant and sampled agave-based beverages. Last but not least, I had an opportunity to dine at the home of a local family. Adriana was a great guide and companion for this very memorable experience.

Column86: Adriana was the perfect host for our food tour of Mexico City. We arrived for the tour a bit early to get some uncrowded photos of our family in the Zocalo, and met up with Adriana at tour time. After introducing the group of 10 participants, we took a short walk to a local market where we were treated to a delicious breakfast of tamales and a traditional Mexican chocolate drink. There were three in our family, so we ordered one of each variety and got to sample all of them. (Our favorites were the mole and the verde!) We then walked back to the Zocalo, learning some history about the City and its inhabitants along the way. Adriana gave us all a quick lesson on how to use the Mexico City subway, and we were off on a quick ride out to a huge local market. (Pro tip – the subway doors only stay open for 5 seconds at each stop!) The market was amazing, with anything and everything you would ever need for a life in the city. We were able to taste several fantastic foods, including concentrated mole, fresh jimaca with chili powder, and some wonderful Oxacan cheese, to name a few. Adriana also helped us shop for the ingredients to make our own salsa, which was a highlight of the day as we had an entire restaurant to ourselves just outside the main market. Throughout the day, Adriana was full of energy and ready to answer all of our questions. Even our 10 year old was engaged the whole time! Thank you Adriana for a wonderful day and for sharing your passion with us.

Column101: The best authentic tour experience! Come hungry and leave amazed!
Column104: This was a truly unforgettable experience. My guide was very friendly and knowledgeable. I learned so much about the history of the City and every question I had was answered. The food was incredible and there was a lot!! Come hungry!! The art that was hidden in the market was incredible and I would never have found this on my own. The markets were vibrant and the highlight there for me were the flower vendors. What a treat for the senses! Navigating and learning about the metro is super useful for any visitor to CDMX. Finally, the cooking lesson at the end was so fun and delicious. The family run business where it takes place was welcoming and the lovely lady who runs it was so sweet! I loved this whole experience. This is one of the very best values I have ever received from any tour at any place!

Column31:
Our group of 4 loved this tour! We did a city tour afterward and it felt so boring in comparison. This one was fun, interesting, unique, and full of cool stories. If you're visiting Kensington/Chinatown, you have to do this - without it, you'd miss the deep history and meaning behind what you're seeing. You would miss out on a lot.. Kieran gave us a deeper appreciation for the area - the beautiful art (!!) , the history, and the stories behind the buildings and people.

Kieran was a FANTASTIC guide - friendly, funny, welcoming, and a great speaker & storyteller. He shared so many meaningful stories and fun facts. We loved it! Made the tour so interesting and fun!

One thing to note: the tour says 3 hours, but if your group is small, it might be shorter. That didn’t bother us at all - we care more about quality than the exact length. It still felt full and complete.

The pace was great too. I liked that it wasn’t rushed and had a good balance of walking, listening, and a little resting. I also loved the coffee shop Kieran took us to—it was quirky, fun, and sparked some conversation and laughs… (but I won't give away the details!)

This tour is more for people who enjoy something unique, fun..... especially if you appreciate diverse cultures, local history, and understanding how a neighborhood came to be the way it is. It’s not your average city tour, and that’s what makes it so special and fun.

Overall, a beautiful, memorable experience!

Column7: Learn all about Toronto’s beer scene—and enjoy a range of local beer tastings as you go—on a walking tour of the city’s best pubs and historic neighborhoods. Traveling with a guide ensures you see unmarked points of interest that most visitors miss if exploring on their own. You’ll hear about the history of beer in the city, visit three highly rated pubs, and get help navigating St. Lawrence Market. A small-group size means plenty of personal attention.

Column41: This tour is a must for visitors to Toronto. Our guide, Kieran, was outstanding. The walking portion of the tour is short, but pleasant. You see green space along with interesting architecture. We heard many intriguing historical facts along with very tasting some fantastic treats! Each item we tried was delectable and it was difficult to find a favorite. The St. Lawrence Market is such a cool place to find fabulous food, a multitude of sweets and unique souvenirs. We will definitely visit the market on our next visit to the city.

Column56: Try to book with Jason - he’s the best!!
Column59: My daughter and I did the tour of St Lawrence market with Jason and agreed he was one of the very best tour guides we’ve ever had. Fun, funny, incredibly knowledgeable and chock full of terrific local stories, he made 3 delicious hours fly by! Among the tastings? Apple cake, bagels, blintzes, pierogis, Nanaimo bars, peameal bacon sandwich with maple mustard and more! We were stuffed by the end and knew so much more about Toronto. Highly recommend!!!!

Column49: Due to airline scheduling issues, we found ourselves with a full day layover in Paris. Although short, our time in Paris was made memorable via a delightful afternoon with Vivienne as he lead us on a visit to the Latin Quarter (Pantheon, The Sorbonne, and the Cathedral of St Etienne du Mont) and St Germain ( Luxembourg Gardens, the Cathedral of St Sulpice....of DaVinci Code fame and last, but not least, Macrons at Pierre Herme) neighborhoods. Born and raised in Paris, Vivienne showed us Paris through the eyes of a local, combining history with culture as he talked about his city. Lastly, we finished our excursion with a fine selection of French cheeses and terrific wine at a local shop. By avoiding the standard tourist traps one might expect, we had the pleasure of experiencing Paris as if we lived there also. Well done Vivienne.

Column56: Essential tour for a successful trip to Paris
Column59:
Absolutely wonderful, informative informal tour of Latin Quarter and St. Germain. Our tour guide Vivien, a true Parisien, not only educated us about the historical places on the tour, he pointed out sights where movies and tv shows were filmed in the area. We also appreciated Vivien's commentary putting the French, and particularly Parisien, culture and personality in historical perspective. My wife and I came away with a better understanding of who the French are. Finally, Vivien had some great insights into what cafe's and bakeries to avoid, who and when to tip, and other inside information that made the rest of our trip a success.

If possible, do the tour on your first day in Paris. Vivien's inside info was essential for the success of the rest of our trip.

Column65: Always more to see and enjoy in Paris
Column68:
We'd chosen the tour as an intro to Paris for my inlaws, who were visiting for the first time. The weather gods were not kind and it was very cold and drizzly to begin with our lovely guide Vivien, with our agreement, shook thinks up a bit and we toured from beautiful church to beautiful church rather than followed the prescribed itinerary.

As a Parisien himself Vivien was a font of knowledge, amusing and great company on our explorations. Seeing the olds were flagging he tailored the tour to suit and we ended with a lovely charcuterie plate and wine under heaters sheltering from the chill.

I think the description is inaccurate as it is more a walking tour with a few snacks at the end, however ignoring the misnomer it was an enjoyable and informative tour, for both newbies and old friends of Paris. Vivien gets 5 stars, the mislabeling of the tour brings it down to 4.

Column83: Absolute best tour we have done!!!

We did the Experience Bohemian Paris tour yesterday and it was the most fun, enjoyable and amazing tour we have done EVER! It was just us so we had our guide, Doina, all to ourselves. She made the tour so lively and fun but she was also very knowledgeable and informative. She never bombarded you with too much information but what she did impart, she did so with humor and ease.
I highly recomend this tour to anyone who wants to really experience Paris, not just visit the tourist attractions. Well worth your money.

Column104:
Doriana was our wonderful guide Into the insightful work of local Parisians. We stopped by the oldest bakery and went down to the basement where the baker worked and places the breads In the woodfire oven. Stopped for delectable desserts in the medical where the oldest restaurant in Paris resides.
Another stop at Candle makers for Kings, noblemen and revolutionaries like Neapolitan. Ending the tour with some wine tasting and treats like foie gras, while local Parisians pile in for their post work aperitifs. Came back feeling like a local. The best way to experience Paris. Thank you Doriana.

Column2: Hidden Paris: Explore Medieval Marais on a Walking Tour
Column7: Discover the Marais district of Paris on a guided walking tour that illuminates the history and culture of the well-preserved medieval neighborhood. Pass by landmarks such as Hôtel de Ville and la Place de la Bastille and discover hidden gems, and stop to sample a sweet treat from a local bakery. This small-group tour allows for a more personalized experience.
Column14:
Highlights
Sample a delicious sweet treat while exploring the Marais
Walk the district at a leisurely pace suitable for most people
Learn about the district’s importance to Jewish and LGBTQ+ communities
Small-group tour with numbers limited to 12 people, with private option

Column20: A big thank you to Benoit who was my tour guide today (and just mine! I felt rather spoiled) and as other reviews mention an absolute fountain of information. There was no question he couldn't answer and his passion and interest for Paris and its history was lovely. If you prefer to explore on foot and see a city the way its locals see it you will enjoy this tour. If you have a sweet tooth you will also very much enjoy the delicious little pastry treat partway through - although you'll be tempted to come back for 10 more.

Column56: Good but wrong description - this is NOT a food tour
Column58: The tour itself was good, but singularly there would be 5 stars - if you knew what to expect and consciously paid for it. Unfortunately it had nothing to do with the title "Wine, cheese and pastries in the Marais" but was completely free of food and drinks except for a mini-sweet pastry. Very unfortunate, as we had booked the tour especially as a "wine-cheese-food tour". The title and description of the tour are therefore urgently to be updated. I am trying to get a refund from the organizer.

Sales S
Hi Robert, Thank you for your recent review. We are sorry to learn of your disappointment in the tour you purchased for you time in Paris. We have looked at your complaint and are quite sure that while you may have intended to purchase a wine tour, that in actuality you did purchase the https://www.viator.com/tours/Paris/Hidden-Paris-Discover-Medieval-Marais-on-a-Walking-Tour/d479-5944P3 which is inclusive of a local English speaking guide and a croissant. When looking at wine and cheese tours there is nothing listed that coincides with the price range of your ticketing. We do believe this to have been an error perhaps in selecting the tour you intended, and the one that you booked. We do believe that the tour you purchase is what was delivered, and therefore will not be providing a refund to you at this time. We are happy to provide to you a 10% Future Booking Voucher as a gesture of goodwill, and we do hope that you managed to enjoy your time in Paris. With thanks, Michelle

Column2: Tapas, Drinks & Stories: Madrid by Night Food Tour
Column7: Knowing the best spots in Madrid for an authentic taste of Andalusian cuisine can be difficult. Avoid the tourist traps and learn about the city’s gastronomic scene on a tour of the city center, Literary Quarter, and Lavapiés neighborhood. Sample five traditional tapas (snacks or appetizers) and sip on Spanish wine, as you chat with your guide about the city’s cultural heritage. Receive personalized recommendations and enjoy an intimate experience on this small-group tour.

Column7: Exploring Athens without a guide means you may miss out on lesser known sights and the background on its classical treasures. This private tour takes you along the perimeter of the Acropolis and also visits hidden gems: Peruse the food and flea markets in and around Monastiraki, and see the Agora and Hadrian’s Library.

Column20: We had a great private tour with Babis who is so knowledgeable about his home town of Athens. We started in the markets then walked through old Athens and Plaka finishing at the Acropolis museum. All the time Babis talked about the history of Athens, showed us old ruins, explained their timeline and pointed out the different architecture throughout the city. We even had a coffee stop at a rooftop restaurant with an incredible view over old Athens towards the Acropolis. I can definitely recommend this tour as part of your Athens experience

Column30:
We had a fantastic tour last Tuesday 15th September with Babis.

We thoroughly enjoyed learning/experiencing some of the old history, religious buildings, architecture, neighbourhoods and ruins of the city and experiencing the sights and smells of the many markets on offer. All brought to life by Babis, who’s knowledge was remarkable and really went the extra mile to show us more for his beautiful city.

It was also a great tour to do on our first day, to find our bearings and gain a geography of all the landmarks. A welcome coffee break was included halfway through on a rooftop cafe overlooking Monastiraki Square, with great views of the Acropolis - a very nice touch.

Thank you urban adventures and thank you Babis.

Column85:
I had an amazing morning in Athens. On this tour you will see Athens from a different and more local perspective. First we strolled through the beautiful markets in the city center. There you find amazing herbs and spices, a lot of nuts, handmade soaps, olives, olive oils and so much more. All local products of Greece where you can find unique gifts and souvenirs for a good price.
Later we did a walk through the center and stopped on a view very beautiful churches and chapels. So much history in downtown that is easy to miss when you walk on your own. Then you stop for a greek coffee in the most beautiful rooftop with an amazing view of the city center and acropolis. Best.stop.ever! The tour continues through very small and hidden pathes with island flair. You pass beautiful old houses (the first houses in Athens) and street art.

Our Guide George was super friendly and knowledgeable. He really likes to share the passion about his country. George is also very helpful with information what to do after the tour and were to go next. He also answers every question you have.

Thank you so much for a great morning in Athens. Its the perfect way to start your visit in Athens.
Read more

Column67:
We met our tour guide, Charlotte Mich, near the main markets of Athens and she took us through the meat and fish areas as well as the antiquities area and streets with spices, oils and herbs. There was so much to see and she was really informative and engaging in all we saw. We also went to areas to eat that a tourist would not necessarily go to and had the most delicious Meze and ouzo not to mention tasting different oils and olives in specialist shops. We both really enjoyed our tour and I loved seeing how different the way of life and shopping is in Athens compared to our own. Would highly recommend this tour just please make sure that you do not eat first!!

Column28: Our time in Athens was wonderful and then some!
Column31:
Our first trip to Athens in late September/early October was an absolutely wonderful adventure.

We flew over on Turkish Airlines, which treated us very well; their customer service, flight crew and Business Lounge (in Istanbul through which which we connected) were exceptional.

The car service we used from airport to hotel and back was provided by Welcome Tours; punctual, reasonably priced and very safe driving.

Our hotel in Athens was the Grande Bretagne Athens, situated in the heart of the city on Constitution Square, diagonally adjacent to the Greek Parliament (notable for its hourly Changing of the Guard. The hotel is an old-world gem with high-ceilinged rooms and efficient and friendly staff. The concierge staff was especially helpful.

During our five-night stay, we benefitted tremendously by having booked three private three-hour tours offered by Context Travel; we've now also used them in Dublin, Istanbul, Paris and Rome and they are simply, hands down, the very best! We toured the Acropolis, Parthenon and Acropolis Museum on our first day of touring; the National Archaeological Museum of Athens on the second; and the Ancient Agora with Plaka Neighborhood on the third. Just outstanding tours led by by totally knowledgeable and super friendly tour guides. Words to the wise: Wear very comfortable shoes and always carry water with you.

Lastly our meals: Starting every day with an expansive breakfast buffet at our hotel's Rooftop Restaurant energized our tours of the city. We enjoyed two delicious dining experiences at this same restaurant looking out at the picture-postcard-perfect lit-up Acropolis. Another evening we dined at Tudor Hall in the Grand Bretagne's adjacent sister hotel, the King George; a very elegant, impeccably served and rather pricey restaurant, but a tad more fancy than appetite-satisfying. Cookoovaya was perhaps a more trendy eatery, a little off the beaten path, but with delicious menu, very ample servings and reasonably priced. On our final night in Athens, we were able to get in (reservations way in advance recommended) to Dionysos Zonar's; outdoor dining with a perfect view of the nearby lit-up Parthenon made for a most memorable evening!

During our entire stay in Athens, we felt appreciated, safe and very welcome.
It's a wonderful city with a truly amazing history and so very, very much to offer!

Column2: Athens Moonlight Waling Tour with Drinks and Meze Dishes
Column7: If you’re not sure where to go out at night in Athens, take this guided tour to visit bars and hear live guitar folk music at a bouzoukia venue. You’ll taste local spirits like ouzo and raki at each venue, paired with meze (Greek finger food). Admire rooftop views and secret gardens, and enjoy VIP entry at the bouzoukia. A small-group size means plenty of personal attention.
Column13: This is booked 28 days in advance on average.

Column101: Get a different Athens experience with a fabulous local guide.
Column104: A fabulous way to see Athens come alive at night with a local expert. Theo showed us places and views of the city that we'd never have found as tourists on our own. He was great fun, knowledgeable about the city, its history, culture and politics. The range of venues explored (a variety of smaller family tavernas to hip & hidden bars, funky alleyways, and rooftop bar with breathtaking views of the Acropolis) made this a must-do when you're in Athens. Food & drinks were plentiful. We felt safe and adventurous with Theo's local knowledge. Highly recommended.

Column2: Vienna for Food Lovers: Hidden Cafés & Market Gems
Column7: Love food and new cities but hate tourist-trap eateries? Instead, use your time in Vienna to scout out the coffee shops, chocolatiers, and markets that serve up the city's best bites. This Vienna food tour is packed with tips for places to eat and specialties to try, plus opportunities to discover trendy neighborhoods with your local guide. And with just a small group for company, you're ensured a hassle-free way to explore.
Column14:
Highlights
Explore Vienna with a local guide to avoid the tourist traps
Discover the best places to snack, sip, and savor authentic Viennese food
Enjoy a more local experience on this small-group tour
This tour includes enough tastings to add up to a very generous meal

Column92: Really interesting and filling day in the Vienna suburbs.
Column94:
The tour exceeded our expectations. Different foods, take the ( clean) subway or tram, eat again. During the travel and while eating, our guide Christophe was full of enthusiasm, fun facts and kept us all engaged.
A word of warning, food tour means food, lots of it. Dinner in the evening is out of the question, a light snack is all that you will be able to eat!
This tour was a high point of our visit to Vienna, seeing the life that the locals live and eating what they eat far from the tourist crowds.

Column17: The best part of my weekend trip.
Column20: The best thing about food tours is you don't need to search 'great restaurants near me' or 'authentic Viennese food near me.' The guide takes you to the best of the best, showing you interesting stops, chatting about the culture and history and taking you beyond the tourist hot spots to absolute gems. The food was amazing - do not eat before you go! Peter was so knowledgeable about the history and culture of Vienna and spent more time and energy on us than he needed to! Thanks to him I could use public transport confidently, so thank you Peter!

Column103:
4 of us had the absolute pleasure of going on a wonderful 6 hour (actually went for 7 hours) private food and history tour. A very long tour I admit, but we had so much fun with Peter - world's best guide - the time flew by.
I expected we would visit a couple of coffee cafes and, in accordance with their coffee culture, spend an hour or two at each with a food stop somewhere in between. We did partake of a traditional coffee cafe, but then we did so very much more.
Peter has a gift for telling a story, for bringing history alive. He has an actors way of telling the tale which keeps you memerized and entertained. Bravo Peter, and thank you!
We ate a LOT of new tasty foods, went to places that locals go and of which tourists are unaware. All the while learning the colorful history of beautiful Vienna.
We all left the tour feeling utterly satiated, knowledgeable about Vienna's fascinating history and with a desire to visit Vienna again, physically a little tired but mentally wired, and with an abiding affection for our tour guide Peter.
It was a truly and all around wonderful experience.
Read more

Column2: Vienna After Dark: Private Evening Food & Drink Experience
Column7: For a great night out in Vienna, you can always let your feet lead the way, but then you're likely to miss some of the best nightlife in this bustling city. Don't miss a thing with this after-dark city tour, where you join a private tour for a night on the town. Highlights include tasting chocolate at one of Vienna's popular markets, sampling the city's famous street food, and sipping drinks at a rooftop bar.
Column14:
Highlights
Explore Vienna after dark on this guided, private nightlife excursion
Visit the Naschmarkt, and experience the nightlife hub in the 4th District
Get a great value with an aperitif, glass of wine, and food tasting included
Meet outside Karlskirche—in the 4th District—steps from the Karlsplatz metro

Column28: Must-Do Food and Walking Tour of Vienn
Column30:
Wolfi was our guide for a 4+ hour walking and tram tour throughout Vienna. If you are up for trying some authentic Austrian food, wine and beer and exploring some off-the-tourist path locations, then book this tour! Wolfi is a local with worldly experience and we not only enjoyed the food and the locations, but our conversations with him about Vienna and Austria. Be hungry when you go on this tour…the “small” portions are generous!

Column48:
Melbourne Urban Adventures Bites and Sights Tour is a definite “Bucket List” when visiting Melbourne. Even if you are a regular and trust me your knowledge and understanding of this beautiful City will be greater. The Eureka Skydeck sets the platform for an excellent tour. The Laneway visits along with the Markets make this a fascinating tour. As always the right ingredients make a polished meal. Tour guide Kellie was the key ?? to make this not only a brilliant tour but her likeable and personal touch put the icing on this well baked cake. Kellie is a widely travelled tour guide that not only knows Melbourne but she knows the world. A beautiful person with a soul to match. This group is lucky to have such a person like Kellie. Flexible and easy going too. I would and do recommend this tour to any person. Even if you think you know Melbourne (like I thought I did ) you will be amazed at some of the history and stories to be told. Don’t hesitate to book a Tour with Urban. Integrity and professional is how I would label them Kellie is the best Tour guide ever encountered and have no hesitation in recommending her 101%. Cheers S
Read more

Column101: A quirky, entertaining view of a fascinating city.
Column104: Our guide (Tristan) gave us an interesting tour of Melbourne It was very quirky and not what you would expect from some potted, typical tourist tour. The Skydeck whilst I first thought not interesting (we have John Hancock and Sears) was exactly HOW we were able to orient ourselves to the city. It was also really fun to get a young person's view of the city..as we are retired. It gave us a really interesting perspective on life for someone... not our age. He was very personable, low key and it was clear he wanted us to get a real feel for the city. I wish it had been longer. He had some great things to share..and it was much more lively and entertaining than the usual tour. It made me fall in love with Melbourne.

Column17: A great morning at the market
Column20:
A great way to spend a few hours hearing about the history of the market and sampling the best the market has to offer. Some very generous samples were included from a number of vendors in the market, plus a coffee, gelato and donut.

Tour guide Tristian was extremely knowledgeable about the market and had some great recommendations for things to do and see around Melbourne. Definitely recommend for locals or tourists.

Column28: A decent tour into the QVM
Column31:
I took this tour as part of a free promotion, but I believe it's decently priced at $75, given the small group size and the included tastings like an oyster, a borek, and gelato.

As a local, it was hard to be impressed by a tour of the Queen Victoria Market, but I did learn a few new things, which was a pleasant surprise.

However, the tour's framing felt misleading. While the market itself is multicultural, the tour was not.

The guide's approach to food could be seen a culturally insensitive. The guide showed little knowledge or appreciation for certain cuisines, describing them with a hint of disdain that could easily offend. This was highlighted by her judgmental tone when she discussed the market's 'unhygienic' past, a comment that seemed to ignore the reality of how many traditional wet markets operate worldwide.
On the converse the guide celebrated European food with great enthusiasm.

In the end, the tour felt whitewashed and failed to genuinely celebrate the market's diversity.
Slightly disappointed in Intrepid and perhaps some unconcious bias training is in order.
(As in the guide probably didn't even realise how they could come across to some people.)

Also I felt it was worthwhile to mention that the the guide also showed little empathy for three small business's that are in the precinct with a purpose that secretly they want displaced / relocated to allow other social enterprises that space. Sure I get it, but they're small business owners too.

Column2: Washington DC Moonlight Tour by Electric Cart
Column7: See Washington, D.C., monuments and landmarks on an evening tour by electric vehicle. Exploring D.C. after dark means seeing the landmarks dramatically lit, and the quiet, open-sided vehicle gives unobstructed views and great photo opportunities. From the Jefferson Memorial to the White House, and Capitol Hill, and a moving series of memorials, you’ll see some of D.C.’s top sights with historic context from a guide.

Column2: DC Monuments and Capitol Hill Tour by Electric Cart
Column7: Exploring Washington DC's monuments and memorials in an open-sided electric cart means you can enjoy unobstructed views from beginning to end. Traveling with a small group (or just a guide, if you select the private option), you'll cover popular destinations in the heart of DC, and hear stories throughout the tour. Stop to visit highlights including the Lincoln Memorial, the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial, the White House, and more.

Column2: Explore Casablanca: Highlights of Medina, Views & Local Flavors
Column7: Get under the skin of dynamic Casablanca on a small-group guided tour, with transfers from your central starting point. See highlights such as the gigantic Hassan II Mosque, the “sqala” fortifications, the Mahkama du Pacha palace, the Quartier Habous shopping district, and Rick’s Café, a tribute to the classic movie. Visit a bakery and a pastry store, and enjoy a cup of tea or coffee.

Column74: Exceptional Casablanca tour with Hicham Bennis
Column77: Morocco was on my must see list. I booked a private tour with Urban Adventures by Intrepid. I arrived an hour earlier than expected and Hicham came and greeted me right away. He was very professional and yet was like a friend taking us around. I had a remarkable day. If you are a photographer, you will appreciate his eye for getting the right angle. He stopped multiple times for us to take photos, and even took some photos for us. A highlight was picking out pastries and cookies and then going to a cafe to drink mint tea and eat our treasures. It was so good to learn the history of the city and architecture. We learned so much, and the time went quickly. I wholeheartedly recommend Urban Adventures Morocco. If you are doing a private tour, ask for Hicham. You will be so glad you did!

Column101: Good Tour of Casablanca- Be aware of terrible lunch
Column104: We did the Urban Adventure Tour with local guide Mohammed. While he was personable and friendly we found him to be condescending at times, and after speaking extensively with other guides we’ve come to realise that information he told along the way had very little factual basis which made for a charming story but didn’t give us a full picture of Casablanca. I thoroughly enjoyed what I did see during the tour and I do feel it’s a worthwhile tour to do to gain a good bearing of the city. The main let down for us is Mohammed took us for a lunch and told it was authentic when really it was a friend of his restaurant aimed at tourists. The lunch was rather expensive for Morocco and was absolutely dismal, we were trapped into paying for a full set menu despite not being that hungry. Mohammed then demanded a tip for the driver and himself - which having done yours in the past is usual. We tipped him generously and he seemed displeased. This unpleasant ending to the trip just left a bad taste in my mouth.

Hi Mackenzie, Thank you for your recent review. We are sorry to know that you did not have the experience as we always aim to deliver. We will be discussing your review with Mohammed in order to develop him in the ways that he is lacking- we apologize if you ever felt your guide to be condescending- this should never happen. The restaurant and outcome that your guide provided to you will also be reviewed. While we understand that Morocco is very much a tipping culture, the amounts should always be received with thanks. We appreciate the time you have taken to let us know about your experience, Mackenzie, and should you think to come along with us again we hope that you would consider a 15% Future Booking Voucher for the negative experience. We are happy to learn that you did have some positives from your tour time, and we hope that you enjoyed your time in Morocco. Stay well.

Column68:
We got to explore the spiritual tour with Hicham. He is VERY knowledgeable and knew every detail of each museum we visited. He took great pictures of us at Hassan II Mosque and waited patiently as we took pictures/videos. Because we are Jewish he was able to get us into Beth-El and the oldest synagogue in Casablanca. He checked in on us several times and very easy to get along with!

There was one part of the experience that was not as good but it was not the fault of Hicham so we didn’t take any stars away from that. Toward the beginning we waited for the taxi driver to pick us up, but he was late. This created problems for Hicham as he made several calls to him and had an argument with another person that wanted to set us up with one of his taxis. Once the taxi driver picked us up (he has a contract with agency) he “appeared” very upset and would not let it go for most of our drive to and from other places. I mention appeared because I’m not sure if this was just his personality but based on the back and forth that happened it didn’t seem so.

Everything went very well with Hicham but the driver did not add well to the experience. As mentioned we did not want to take away stars since this was not Hichams fault.

Column101: Fun way to learn about Casablanca and see the city!
Column104: I did the religious morning tour my first morning in Casablanca, with Bennis Hicham as my guide. I lucked out and was the only person on the tour! You get access to the Mosque, where you visit the museum and join the official tour group there. Bennis then takes you around to a few different church’s and synagogues. What stands out is the historical context that he provides during the tour—it makes the locations more meaningful when you understand the significance. There was plenty of time to take pictures, and because it was the two of us, we were able to go to a few locations that don’t typically allow the large busses of group tours inside. It was clear that Bennis wanted me to see all the highlights of Casablanca, and we had a lot of laughs during the day! The tour ended with a walk through the new Medina, where we stocked up on pastries from a local shop and drank mint tea at a cafe. Overall, it was a great way to see the city comfortably, with good company.

Column2: A Night in the Medina: Food, Flavors & Culture
Column7: Experience the culinary secrets of Djemaa el Fna on a half-day food tour of this bustling Marrakech square and UNESCO World Heritage Site. Whet your appetite with a wide range of treats, walk through the maze-like food markets, and sit down to a full dinner in the heart of Djemaa el Fna. Explore with a small group that's capped at 12 food lovers to ensure a more personalized experience.

Column17: Taste of Morocco for a night
Column20: The tour Was really a very small group. Just me and the guide JIHAD!! It was quick and informative. So We had moroccan mint tea wirh local naan bread, sardine sandwich, local minestrone soup, kuskus, some desserts. Food in General Was bland for my personal taste. But Thats How they do it here. Interesting How the local moroccan desserts are reallu sweet, bees were ALL over the dessert shop. . Its good to have a tour Like this to sample ALL the little food that I wouldnt normally try on my own. Was expecting little portions, But Was more than full after the tour. Thanks for the wonderful food tour

Column59: Our guide Brahim met us and we were lucky enough to be the only 2 on the tour so had a private guide! He was very chatty with good English and explained some of the history of Marrakesh as well as the traditions and origins of the foods we tried and sharing some recipes. There was loads to eat and we were glad we arrived hungry, we also enjoyed some traditional mint tea. We both really enjoyed the experience and would definitely recommend this, by going on the second day of our trip we got some top tips on what to try during the rest of our trip, we also got advice on how to haggle in the souks and the best / safest ways to navigate the footpaths and roads.

Column94:
Evening Marrakech: Gastronomic and
Market Tour Inside the Medina
We met our friendly guide Brahim and the British couple that were also on the tour. Brahim explained the tour for us and we began walking around the Medina, starting in the Jewish quarter where we got to taste tea and freshly baked doughnuts, not like any we have tasted before. Thin crust and soft in the middle. Next stop was to taste different olives, spiced, green and black. Even those on the tour who didn't like olives found some of these very good. Now our guide stopped by a sweet booth where he bought some dessert for us to have after the main dinner. The main dinner was a delicious slow cooked meat in a restaurant that was already closed, since they close when everything is sold out. Our guide had reserved this for us. The last food we had was a homemade soup served at a stall in the middle of the square by the sons of the woman who cooked it earlier. Before we said goodbye, we had a spiced hot drink similar to Gluck wine or a Christmas drink. Brahim told us a lot about the culture and cuisine in Morocco. We highly recommend Brahim and this tour.

Read more

Column2: Explore Marrakech Medina: Private Tour Including Bahia Palace Visit
Column7: Explore the maze-like souks of the Marrakech medina on a half-day walking tour that includes Djemaa el Fna, Bahia Palace, and the Photography Museum of Marrakech. Experience all this historic neighborhood has to offer as you are guided through some of the city’s unique spice shops and traditional bakeries, for a fascinating introduction to daily life in Marrakech’s old center.
Column14:

Column56: Best tour to get to know Marrakech
Column59: I had a tour with Mo. He is the best tour guide you can image. We walked to historical places and he very well explained the history behind every single monument. We visited the museum of photography, the palace of Bahia, Saadian tombs. Then we visited the famous bakery where locals bake their bread and the hammam over (Farran) where locals leave their tangia to be made. The highlight of the tour was visiting the places where they cook Méchoui (upon my request)! He is super nice and I highly recommend him to all my friends who want to visit and have a nice time in Marrakech.

Column77: Our wonderful guide Mounir, was inedible insightful and fun to be around. He was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic about Marrakesh where he was born and bred. My daughter and I were eager listeners and came with many questions all which Mounir had answers too. We enjoyed our time with Mounir very much. He extended the tour by two hours out of kindness and because we were so keen to learn and see more. The Bahia palace was a special treat not least because Mounir managed to navigate the crowds so it appeared we had most of the palace to ourselves most of the time. A trip to the Hammam engine, below ground, was another highlight. Playing music with a local musician also a fantastic experience. Highly recommend this tour. Ask for Mounir

Column86: I didn't end up going on this tour, as I got very sick the night before and had to cancel. The sickness wasn't their fault, but I did expect to receive some kind of response from them about rescheduling. When this didn't happen, I had to make alternative plans and sent a third email asking if there was any possibility of getting any refund. Again, no answer. An extremely frustrating experience!!!

Column2: From Market to Table: Tajine Cooking Class in Marrakech
Column7: Cook a feast of regional foods with a small-group Marrakech cooking class that includes lunch in a traditional Moroccan home. Since you’ll go all the way from market-fresh ingredients to a finished meal, this cooking class is a great way to learn techniques and recipes that you can easily recreate in your home kitchen.
Column13: This is booked 26 days in advance on average.
Column14:
Highlights
Visit the famous Jemaa el-Fnaa market to shop for ingredients and spices
Prepare a traditional Moroccan dish you can recreate at home
Chance to experience Moroccan hospitality in a local house
Bring home recipes: the class includes a souvenir collection

Column46: From Souk to Stove: The Best Tagine in Morocco!
Column48:
The Marrakech Tour - Tagine Cooking Class was easily one of the best experiences of our trip. Our host guided us through the vibrant souks to gather fresh ingredients, and visiting the butcher—with live chickens in the back—was a real, authentic glimpse into daily Moroccan life.

After shopping, we were welcomed into a stunning Riad where the cooking began. We prepared a Moroccan tomato salad, zalouk, and a chicken tagine. After two weeks of tagines across Morocco, I can confidently say this was the best one we had—and not just because I made it!

The recipes were provided at the end, and we’ve already recreated the meal at home. It instantly transported us back to the smells, tastes, and atmosphere of Marrakech.

Highly recommend this class for anyone looking to take home more than just souvenirs—this is a memory you can relive with every bite.
Read more

Column59: I booked this experience for me and my friend for my birthday. Laila was such a great chef/host. We walked to the market, which was a bit of a trek so bring some walking shoes, if it was a bit shorter, I’d give this 5 stars. Though it was cool to see all the stores along the way to getting our ingredients for dinner. Once we made it back the riad, which is STUNNING by the way, we were given time to rest with tea and biscuits. Then we go to work. This was such a fun and interactive experience. Laila is very helpful, patient, and funny! We made chicken tagine, baba ghanoush, Moroccan salad, and bread! It was all so delicious and highly recommend.

Column101: Great cooking class in the heart of the Medina
Column104:
This cooking class was a fantastic experience! We started with a brief tour of the local markets where Leila, our chef and guide, showed us where she buys fresh ingredients. After picking everything out, we headed back to the riad where most of the prep work was already done, so we could jump straight into cooking. Leila guided us through making chicken tagine, Moroccan salad, zalouk, bread, and mint tea, offering great tips on spices and techniques.

While the tagine cooked, we relaxed on the rooftop terrace with tea. The meal was incredible, and we enjoyed it together as a group. We also received a small bag of spices to take home. Highly recommend this class for anyone looking to experience authentic Moroccan cooking!

Column2: Pashupatinath Temple and Bodhnath Stupa Tour from Kathmandu
Column7: Pashupatinath—dedicated to Lord Shiva, the patron deity of Nepal—is one of the world’s holiest Hindu temples, and Boudhanath is a 14th-century Buddhist stupa located within Nepal’s “Little Tibet.” This tour visits both UNESCO-listed religious sites in Kathmandu. You’ll even have a chance to meet a well-known Nepali astrologer for an optional reading. A small group makes for an intimate atmosphere, and the tour includes all entrance fees for a seamless experience.
Column13: This is booked 24 days in advance on average.
Column14:
Highlights
Informative combo tour of Pashupatinath and Boudhanath
Cover both UNESCO-listed religious sites in a single outing
Travel by local transportation for a slice of everyday Kathmandu life
Upgrade to include a reading with a famous local astrologer
Observe the mesmerizing evening prayer called "aarti" on the riverbanks of Pashupatinath Temple
This tour is carbon neutral, operated by the world’s largest travel B Corp accredited company.

I had three wonderful experiences with Intrepid travel, the main stupa and Pashupatinath temple on day one - a local Kathmandu panoramic hike on day two and a morning tour of the Darbar square and Monkey temple on day three.

I’m very glad I booked these as I saw all the main sites of Kathmandu in just three days. The tours were well organised and I managed see everything I wanted in a short space of time.

A big thanks for Yogi who was very conscientious and knowledgeable. I enjoyed our discussions about Buddhist and Hindu culture and history a great deal.

Column20:
First time visiting Thailand as a solo traveler. I was extremely surprised to find I was the only participant for the afternoon excursion. My guide Art was absolutely wonderful!!! He was extremely knowledgeable, answered all of my questions, and was so kind.

The EV Tuk Tuk was a great way to explore different parts of Bangkok in the oppressive heat. We also took a quick river ride to visit the very cool flower market that is open 24 hrs.

My favorite spots included the Wang Lang market and Ban Bu community.
Art even made an extra stop to highlight a local temple where imagery was used in the White Lotus. Such a fun fact!!!

Thank you Art for sharing a wonderful day and showcasing some amazing parts of your country’s rich culture ????????

Column38: Fantastic Day Adventure by Tuk tuk!
Column40:
Three weeks ago I took the Intrepid Urban Adventures Bangkok “Old Bangkok Temples and Markets by Tuk-Tuk” tour. I was surprised to find that I was the only booking for the morning. I promptly met my wonderful guide Ait at the meeting point and he brought us to our tuktuk driver that shuttled us throughout the morning. Ait was a newer guide but I thought he was great! He spoke fair English and we had some interesting conversation about the area, the world and beyond. Wat Pho the Reclining Buddha and the Mont temple are a must see. We also got to see children practicing their instruments and traditional dance at the temple. We visited the flower market and he folded me a flower (pic). He even bought me an iced latte in the marketplace when I was sweating thru my shirt. If you are in Bangkok for a day or two, this is an enjoyable 4 hour tour. Thank you, Ait! Sawadi ka! ?????? ?? Susannah
Read more

Column101: Stay in the moment of adventure.
Column104: I learned so much about Thai- Chinese history, and experienced all kind of Chinese food on the way. Apple was very knowledgeable and I appreciate her way of relating very much to other cultures. The best food experience where the Chinese coffee shop, the chives and pork dumplings. It was worth trying for the icecream made from soy sauce and the pork in rolled noodle soup. The drinks at the rooftop bar were very much appreciated as they provided a fabulous view over Bangkok at night, from the Old city to the business quarters if the city. Huge thank you for a wonderful tour.

Column17: A great way to see the must-sees of Bangkok
Column20: This was a great tour with guide Pam who had so much knowledge about everything, we learnt so much and she was a lot of fun. We booked the tour for four of us. The meeting point was easy to find and the tour started with a longboat ride where we saw basking lizards and fed catfish. We then disembarked and walked a short walk to The Grand Palace which was incredible in its opulence and history. The Emerald Buddha was in its winter coverings. We then jumped on an air con bus to Wat Pho to see the incredible Reclining Buddha. It is hard to find words to describe these places, they have to be seen. We finished with a cafe stop. I am glad we did this tour early in the morning before it gets too hot and too crowded. Pam took care of all the entry tickets. Perhaps the only thing that could have made it better would be to do the longboat ride in between the two venues to have a breather. But the tour is only 4 hours!

Column68:
I came across this tour after a recommendation from a fellow traveller and I was thoroughly surprised on an area of the city I haven't yet come across in the time I have been in Bangkok.
A much more relaxing way to explore the city on a traditional longtail boat, which is owned by a local, and with the help of the guide, they shared their own stories which helped to provide a real local experience. After the boat, we were taken to the enchanting Grand Palace and learnt more about the Buddhism.
As a solo traveler, I really enjoyed seeing an alternative area of the city, away from all the crowds, with real local people.

Column92: Temple highlights with a relaxing cruise
Column95: Started with a peaceful wander around Wat Pho, taking in the culture. Then the canal cruise which was nice too, especially stopping to feed the fish in the river. We then went to the amazing Grand Palace which was pretty mesmerising however, be warned, it is extremely crowded. We chose not to see the emerald Buddha due to the length of the queue and the heat. The entrance ticket includes a traditional Thai show at the theatre not far from the Grand Palace. There are free shuttle buses to the theatre outside. Amin was a good guide, seemed a bit rushed but probably due to the short 4 hour time frame. Very knowledgeable and funny. Overall it was a great tour, would recommend.

Column38: An experience not to be missed
Column41:
we booked the trip via Marriott Bonvoy app (lnked with viator/TA) - to get some points (that has yet to be received on our end), but anyway, it was truly the highlight of our holiday!
Guided by the ever so friendly and knowledgeable Ms Apple, we started the day in Maeklong train station - arrived in 8.30am to catch the 1st train there and back! we got to sit in a coffee shop beside the railway and got out to catch the train chugging beside us, what an experience. Next on to the coconut processing village - yummy coconuts! lastly, we went to Damnoensaduak Floating Market - also one unique experience, buying souvenirs on a boat! Finished the trip and back in Bangkok town by 2pm - time well spent!
Thanks a lot Ms Apple and Bangkok Urban Adventures!

An experience not to be missed
Nov 2022
we booked the trip via Marriott Bonvoy app (lnked with viator/TA) - to get some points (that has yet to be received on our end), but anyway, it was truly the highlight of our holiday!
Guided by the ever so friendly and knowledgeable Ms Apple, we started the day in Maeklong train station - arrived in 8.30am to catch the 1st train there and back! we got to sit in a coffee shop beside the railway and got out to catch the train chugging beside us, what an experience. Next on to the coconut processing village - yummy coconuts! lastly, we went to Damnoensaduak Floating Market - also one unique experience, buying souvenirs on a boat! Finished the trip and back in Bangkok town by 2pm - time well spent!
Thanks a lot Ms Apple and Bangkok Urban Adventures!

Column58:
Excellent informative trip. We spent the morning with Nai , our guide and Manit our driver. Was picked up at the hotel as we were the only people on the trip. Nai was super friendly and we spent the trip to MaeKhlong exchanging stories nuggets our cultures and where to find good food in Bangkok.

At MaeKhlong, Nai brought us to sample the local Thai fare ( mainly sweet desserts) and a look into a traditional Thai Market.

We also visited a family run coconut sugar farm. (Look out for the super cute and friendly family dog - Fifa)

Explored an authentic floating market and more than ample time to explore the market ourselves and sample the local fare.

Manjit was instrumental in us reaching our destinations on time (especially to watch the train pass by the market). An excellent safe and experienced driver. Vehicle was clean and comfortable.

Would definitely recommend this trip. Learnt and experience Thai life outside of Bangkok

Column67:
We enjoyed our tour of the city of Hanoi with our knowledgeable guide, An. It was great having a driver who got us safely through each location. We started with the Temple of Literature which was built in honor of Confucius in 1970. It became a University accepting students from the aristocracy society in 1076. We continued our tour visiting a traditional tea house where we heard about the importance of tea to the Vietnam Culture. We had delicious Lotus Flower Tea with traditional Green Bean Cake. We stopped at the infamous “Hanoi Hilton “. This place holds a dark place in history first as prison used by the French to imprison Vietnamese people and later used by the Vietnam soldiers to imprison American Prisoners of War. We then visited the beautiful Ngoc Son Temple located at the beautiful Hoan Kiem Lake. Our guide, An made this experience even more special by sharing stories and traditions from that era. stopped at Pho Thin a local lunch spot for some delicious Pho, Chinese donuts, and ice tea. We finished our tour visiting the impressive St. Joseph Cathedral which had a French Style Gothic Architecture. We can not say enough how much we enjoyed the tour and our personable and professional guide, An.
Read more

Column101: A Perfect Day in the Mekong Delta!
Column104:
If you're looking for a way to escape the hustle and bustle of Ho Chi Minh City and experience a completely different side of Vietnam, this Mekong Delta tour is an absolute must! From start to finish, everything ran smoothly, and all provisions were perfectly taken care of — not a single detail was overlooked.

Our guide, Thanh, was exceptional — friendly, knowledgeable, and full of fascinating insights about the region. His storytelling made the history and culture of the Delta come alive. The drive to My Tho took around 2.5 hours, and from there, our private boat ride down the Mekong River was the perfect way to begin the adventure.

We visited a local fish farm and saw firsthand how the local industries thrive here. Sampling tropical fruits on a lush island was a refreshing treat, and the stop at the coconut candy factory was both educational and delicious! Thanh explained the entire candy-making process, and of course, we got to try some for ourselves.

One of the highlights was traveling by Xe Loi through local villages, which gave us a genuine glimpse into daily life. The bee farm visit was sweet (pun intended!), and the rowing boat ride through the narrow canals was peaceful and beautiful — a moment of true tranquility.

Lunch at Vuon Dau was a culinary delight. Thanh helped us navigate the menu and introduced us to some unforgettable local dishes. It was the perfect ending to a truly immersive experience.

I highly recommend this tour to anyone wanting to see the real Vietnam beyond the city. It was informative, relaxing, and incredibly fun. Thank you, Thanh, for making it such a memorable day!

Column2: Ho Chi Minh City by Night: Ultimate Street Food Experience
Column7: Even if you love to eat Vietnamese food back home, the sheer culinary range on offer in the country can be bewildering. Discover Southern Vietnamese cuisine on this Ho Chi Minh City foodie walking tour led by a gastronomic guide. Besides favorites, such as coffee and beer, savor specialties, such as squid soup (chao muc) and Chinese-style dim sum (ha cao).

Column2: Cu Chi Tunnels Experience from Ho Chi Minh City
Column7: The Viet Cong used the Cu Chi Tunnels during the Vietnam War, and the historic site makes a popular day trip from nearby Ho Chi Minh City. On this tour, benefit from a small group size, which means more attention from your guide and more photo opportunities as you explore the underground tunnels and peek out of the camouflaged trapdoors.

Column2: Private From Cairo: Alexandria Day Trip
Column7: Local guide
Column15:
Ages 0-99
Duration: 10h
Start time: Check availability
Mobile ticket
Live guide: English
More
Column16:
Itinerary
Start
You'll start at
Pharaohs Hotel
12 Lotfy Hassouna, St? Dokki, Giza Governorate 3753441, Egypt
Pharaohs Hotel, 12 Lotfy Hassouna, St, Dokki, Giza Governorate
See address & details
1
Alexandria
Stop: 10 hours
Are you ready for an awe-inspiring day? Then let's get to it! Alexandria is one of the world's most impressive historical cities, and certainly a must-see in Egypt, so if you're thinking about doing this day tour from Cairo...what are you waiting for?! It'll take us about a three hour drive from Cairo before our day tour of Alexandria will truly begin, and where better to kick it off than the Catacombs of Kom Ash-Suqqafa. One of the world's largest Roman burial sites, the Catacombs are one of Alexandria's most popular attractions. Watch your head as you descend into a network of underground passages, tombs, and antechambers via aspiral staircase over a three-level labyrinth (seriously cool, isn't it?!). Dozens of chambers with sculpted pillars and statues await your curiosity, as well as a large Roman-style banquet room, where relatives of the deceased traditionally hosted memorial meals. Our next stop is the National Museum, home to Greek and Roman era masterpiece ruins discovered under the water on the shores of Alexandria. Super impressive old stuff right here! We will enjoy an Egyptian local lunch , Alexandria is famous for its fresh sea food (vegetarian and other dietaries will be accommodated). After lunch we will head to the former site of the Lighthouse of Alexandria, one of the seven ancient wonders of the world. Although the lighthouse is no longer standing, atop its ruins lie the Citadel of Qaitbay, a defensive fortress built in the 15th century. Designed as a defence along the Mediterranean coastline, the Citadel offers extensive views, fresh Mediterranean air, and a supreme sense of historical significance. Our final stop in Alexandria day tour will be the Alexandria Library. Nerd time! Inspired by the original great library of Alexandria, the modern library was built to hold over eight million books. Built between 1995 and 2002, it covers 11 cascading levels and although it has not yet reached its capacity, it's an impressive homage to the ancient splendour of Alexandria. Pick your jaws up off the ground and explore! As one of Egypt’s most historically significant cities, Alexandria really is a must-see for history and culture buffs. We have no doubt it will leave you enriched, impressed, and perhaps a little awe-struck. Following recent safety incidents we recommend that you check your government's advice for their latest information on travelling in Egypt before your departure and ensure that your travel insurance covers you for all areas of your itinerary.
Read more
End
You'll return to the starting point

Column28: Our TOUR & GUIDE Mohamed was JUST FABULOUS! ??
Column30:
I would like to extend my compliments to Mohamed, our tour guide, and Amro, our driver, for the days tour.

I can't thank them enough for their professionalism and nurturing care towards my brother & I. 

This is our first time in Egypt from Australia and I am in awe towards Mohameds knowledge and passion towards tourism and the Egyptian history. We received an exquisite and a beautifully unique experience from Mohamed in the last 2 days. 

A tour guide can definitely make or break your experience and Mohamed made our experience a delightful one. 

Our comfort and experience was his priority and we were heart warmed by his genuine efforts.  I have seen many people from all walks of life in my travel experiences to Bali, Australia, France, America, Mexico, Lebanon, Syria and UAE, together with my profession as a Fraud and Intelligence investigator, and when I come across a genuine person like Mohamed who genuinly loves their job and treats foreigners with kindness, respect and care, they truly deserve a spotlight. I have never received such care for his customers & tourism from any tour guide like Mohamed. Tourism is not just a job for Mohamed, it is a passion and we witnessed his divine knowledge and expertise.  The tour was incredible!!

We highly recommend using urban adventures. Mohammad is a great asset. Having Mohamed as your guide makes the experience. 

We LOVE Egypt ???? and we can't wait to come back!

It is a big day but a day trip is all you need in Alexandria. I highly recommend Urban Adventures and Loay.

Column2: Half-Day Saqqara Pyramids and Memphis Tour from Cairo
Column7: Though the Pyramids of Giza receive crowds of visitors every day, many travelers miss the Step Pyramid of Zoser, the world’s oldest large-scale stone monument. This small-group tour takes you to Saqqara to admire the monument, as well as the relics of Memphis, the ancient capital of Lower Egypt.

Column38: Like a night out with a friend who loves their city and wants you to experience all the things!
Column40:
A highlight of my 3-week trip to Egypt! I did this walking towards the end of my trip when I moved hotels to downtown Cairo after staying near the pyramids. Marwa was a fantastic guide and gave loads of information about recent history, daily life, and her fond memories of downtown hijinks. She took time to learn my interests and pointed out places she thought I’d find particularly interesting, along with the itinerary highlights. As a solo female traveller I would not have ventured out downtown at night - this was a great way to have an evening out on the town :)

Column46: We Learned to Love Cairo with Mina
Column49: Our fascinating walk over the Nile into downtown Cairo with Mina was a treat as he enthusiastically shared his love and deep knowledge of his vibrant city, its rich history, interesting culture and architecture, and beauty. Along the way we were taken to some of his favourite quarters, places where locals were gathering with friends in cafés and restaurants and where we were treated to some of the culinary flavours of Egypt. This walk with Mina really helped us to understand and appreciate the amazing city that Cairo is. By the end of our evening, we felt like we were saying farewell to a good friend.

Column59: Our Tour guide Mina was an awesome guide. He is a friendly, energetic and mainly he listens and understands you. As we walked, he explained to us all the different events that took place in the different routes/areas of Cairo. His has a wealth of knowledge not only of Egypt but in his endeavors globally. Speaking to Mina and getting his response from the heart meant a lot then from someone reading from a manual. We walked through the streets of Cairo downtown, seeing from the heritage structures, enjoying local cuisine, shops and people while still getting an understanding of all amneties. We also experienced the subway and enjoyable experience. Even something like simply crossing a road. Mina made us feel comfortable from start to end. I highly recommend Mina, wishing him all the best in his endeavors.

Column74: Thank you Mina! This Cairo Downtown guide was awesome!
Column77:
Our downtown Cairo tour with Mina was absolutely fantastic! Mina is an outgoing and friendly guide! He was informative, and enjoyable to be with. He showed us some special secret sites of the city… And even made accommodations for us to see some of the things that we wanted to see. He took us to popular patisserie for ice cream and a really good place for dinner for Shawarma! Yummy! He then took us on a metro to see another part of downtown Cairo, and also made sure that we were safe to our final destination back to the hotel. If you have a chance you should get Mina as your guide! He was cognizant of what we wanted to
see as well as flexible and accommodating ! Thank you Mina for a great evening on our last night in Cairo!

Column38: URBAN ADVENTURES THE WORST OF EGYPT
Column41: Lousy tour operator... they do not answer the only phone line they have, plus that line does not have whatsapp, not managing to coordinate the hotel pickup we approached the meeting point specified on the service voucher from 6:00 am to which many cars from different companies arrived, but Urban Adventures Jamas arrived. It was written to the email in view of not having a whatsapp line and not achieving communication and after 4 hours of waiting they reported that they did not have our reservation... in short we had to hire another company at 11:00 am to not lose the day because the next day we took another flight. Actually in Cairo we only stayed for 2 days and we were very sorry with this company that it is incredible that in the 21st century they do not operate a whatsapp line or have an emergency hotline or a chat on their page. Manejan schedules from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm when excursions run from 7:00 am.

Column38: Tasty treats, churches, and organ meats
Column40:
The tour starts with the central market looking at small shops that sell meat/organs, herbal remedies, fruit, flowers, and prepared dishes. The fruit tasting was interesting, as you get a chance to taste fruits not available in the US. The old town is basically a few large churches, the president’s house, and other Catholic Church related buildings. The chocolate tasting was excellent in the variety and quality of chocolate. Overall, the guide was knowledgeable about an area that is somewhat interesting.

Unleash your inner mixologist and discover Peru through its flavors on this fun, hands-on Cusco tour! Master the art of the iconic Pisco Sour, learn about Peru’s beloved Pisco spirit, and shake up the perfect cocktail with the guidance of an expert bartender. Dive into the rich history behind this legendary drink, uncovering the secrets to a perfect mix. Get ready for a flavorful adventure that brings Peru’s vibrant culture to life, one delicious sip at a time!
Read more

Column2: Explore Lima On Bike: Coast Cycling Adventure
Column7: If you’d like to bicycle around Lima but aren’t sure where to go, this private tour shows you the way. Starting in Miraflores, you’ll cycle through the bohemian district of Barranco and up to Morro Solar, finishing back in cosmopolitan Miraflores. It’s an excellent orientation to significant city landmarks, all explained by your guide.

Column65: Not a private cycling experience - misleading.
Column67:
Sadly this was very disappointing, as much as I love to support local businesses. We booked and paid for a Private Coast Cycling Experience to start at 9am, instead we got 6 people on our tour leaving around 10am (no apology, no explanation, no refund).
We do private cycling tours all over the world: that way the guides can customise the ride according to our fitness and enjoyment level (always been successful). Today was not enjoyable and it was clear the guide just wanted to get this tour over and done with. Feel a bit ripped off, plus the fact that I felt embarrassed lagging behind (reason a nearly 60 year old lady booked a private tour and not to race with lovely 30-year olds - felt guilty keeping them up). If you want cheap group tours then yes it’s for you (nothing wrong with it, I was there too once). However if you want a private cycling tour look elsewhere.
Read more

Column83: Fantastic opportunity to learn about local life
Column85:
I was lucky enough to be the only person on the tour so I had Gladys' full attention. We took a public bus to Lima's historic center. Gladys provided a thorough overview of the churches and government buildings along with Lima's history. The real highlight was the walk through the central market. This was what I was looking for. After a week with my friends exploring the tourist attractions around the country I wanted to see how everyday Peruvians lived. I wanted to go off the beaten path. There you can find everything for sale from food to dresses to pots and pans to bags. Unlike other markets such as Marrakech, which itself is a tourist attraction, this market had few tourists and was a true instution that locals shopped at.

I really appreciated the time and attention that Gladys provided to me. After this tour I felt that my trip to Peru was complete.

Thank you!
Read more

Column2: Discover Bucharest: Private Highlights and Traditional Food Tour
Column7: Discover Bucharest’s turbulent history and hearty local flavor on this half-day tour that combines sightseeing with dinner at a traditional Romanian inn. The sprawling capital can be intimidating to explore on your own, so let a guide show you all the major sights, such as Revolution Square, supersized Parliament Palace, and charming Old Town. Then, rest your feet over a 3-course meal of authentic Romanian specialties.
Column14:
Highlights
Combo sightseeing tour and dinner in Bucharest
Explore the Romanian capital’s top sights on a guided walking tour
Learn about the city’s Communist history and be charmed by Old Town
Includes a multicourse meal and drink at a traditional Romanian guesthouse

Column17: Excellent private walking tour and meal in Bucharest.
Column20: This private one on one Discover Bucharest Highlights and Food Tour was excellent. Made especially wonderful by our tour guide Elana (pronounced Ejuana). As a native Bucharest resident and highly educated double master student in history, she was extremely knowledgeable in this field and carried out this tour to perfection. The finishing touch was an excellent Romanian 3 course meal. I highly recommend this tour and hope you get Elana as your guide.

Column46: Such an incredible and personal experience with our guide Mihaela!
Column49:
Mihaela was the most incredible guide!! It was just two of us and we both felt we connected with her as a friend! She offered wonderful personal experiences and context to the historical facts of the places we visited, so we experienced Bucharest through her. She made the tour personable for us, and we had an amazing lunch of sarmale, m?m?lig?, and papana?i for desert! Could not recommend this tour or our wonderful guide Mihaela more.

July was a hot time to go, but we took lots of breaks. Water and a snack (and lunch obviously) is included in the tour, so you’ll be all set!

Column92: Finding the beating heart of Bucharest
Column95: My husband and I were a bit hesitant when we first arrived in Bucharest and saw the communist-era buildings. However, when we joined our walking tour with Elena, she pulled back the concrete curtain and showed us the beating heart of the city. Her energy and passion was evident, and she brought the history of the place to life. There was another group with us for the walking tour, and we then had Elena to ourselves for a traditional lunch at Caru Cu Bere, a historic beer hall. She advised us on our itinerary for the rest of our trip in the countryside, and answered all of our questions. This was the perfect introduction to Romania! Highly recommend.

Column2: Taste Bucharest: A Food Lover's Tour of Markets & Neighbourhoods
Column7: Go deep into Bucharest’s local food culture with an English-speaking guide. Walk through Strada Batistei, the Armenian quarter, the Jewish quarter, Mantuleasa, and Mosilor Street and learn about each place’s history. Taste local cheeses, meats, homemade bread, beers, liquors, and other Romanian food. Snap photos at the traditional Obor Market.
Column13: This is booked 35 days in advance on average.
Column14:
Highlights
Learn about Bucharest’s history from an English-speaking guide
Walk through many different neighborhoods and admire the architecture
Taste a wide variety of local food and drink samples
Visit traditional markets

Column38: Great tour with a super nice guide
Column40:
We accidentally got a private tour. We were the only once who signed up supposedly because of the heat. I am glad the guide still did the tour even with two attendees. The tour was great. We were greeted by our tourguide Andrea who met us with warm pretzels and water at the starting point. We did not bring any backpack or a bag, so she carried the water for us all the time. She was were nice. She started the tour by showing us some architectural gems and telling a bit about history of Bucharest. Then we first stopped at one local restaurant for a plate of Romanian food and beer. Thereafter we moved along too this huge local food market. There were a bit of que but i guess since she was a guide she skipped all the lines and the food and drinks were served quickly. She told us about some other places we shall visit and gaves us recommendations. The guide was talkative, so it was fun to ask her questions. Definitely recommend if you are looking to try some local cuisine and to get to know about local history. Keep in mind that it is a bit hot during summer, but it is possible to do the tour nevertheless and have a good time.
Read more
